Legal_Issue: Validity of Bayer's CIRCLE DESIGN trademark application under the Trade-marks Act
Evidence_Assessment: Errors in color representation (blue vs. pink), lack of clarity on size and first use date, limited distinctiveness due to common pink tablets
Burden_of_Proof: On Bayer to demonstrate compliance and distinctiveness
Credibility_Factor: Evidence showed limited distinctiveness and inaccuracies in application
Legal_Rule: A trademark must be distinctive, comply with statutory requirements, and not mislead; Section 30(h) requires accurate drawings
Procedural_Issue: Review of Registrar's decision with new evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-compliance with statutory requirements, lack of distinctiveness
Key_Evidence_Considered: Color representation discrepancies, size ambiguity, first use date uncertainty, market use of pink tablets
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, visual comparison, market usage data
Decision_Authority: Appellate body under s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Legal_Provision: Section 30(h), Section 56 of the Trade-marks Act
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks, Appellate Review Body
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Inaccurate drawing, non-distinctive mark, misleading color representation
Applicable_Process: Appeal under s. 56 of the Trade-marks Act
